title: LLM-Enhanced Dialogue Management for Full-Duplex Spoken Dialogue Systems
author: Hao Zhang (Tencent AI Lab, Bellevue, USA), Weiwei Li (Tencent AI Lab, Shenzhen, China), Rilin Chen (Tencent AI Lab, Beijing, China), Vinay Kothapally (Tencent AI Lab, Bellevue, USA), Meng Yu (Tencent AI Lab, Bellevue, USA), Dong Yu (Tencent AI Lab, Bellevue, USA)
relevance_why: The paper's focus on improving spoken dialogue systems through an advanced dialogue manager could enhance Haohe Liu's research in audio processing tasks, particularly by adopting techniques for real-time audio interaction management.
background: The paper addresses the challenge of managing turn-taking in spoken dialogue systems, implementing a lightweight semantic voice activity detection module to enhance full-duplex communication.
contribution: This paper introduces a semantic voice activity detection module as a dialogue manager to solve turn-taking challenges in spoken dialogue systems, achieving improved interaction efficiency and accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods rely on acoustic cues for user state detection and often fail to adequately handle interruptions and hesitations, leading to less fluid interactions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances dialogue management by using a fine-tuned large language model to interpret semantic context, allowing for more nuanced and efficient handling of user inputs.

key_innovation: Integrates semantic analysis with acoustic processing to dynamically regulate system interaction based on user intent, improving the quality of real-time dialogues.
real_world_impact: The proposed system could significantly improve user experiences in virtual assistants and customer service applications by enabling more natural and efficient communication. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The study primarily focuses on Chinese dialogues; performance in other languages or diverse accents may not be guaranteed.

new_terms.semantic voice activity detection: **Semantic voice activity detection** refers to the technique of identifying and interpreting user speech patterns and intents through contextual semantics, as opposed to just acoustic signals.
new_terms.full-duplex communication: **Full-duplex communication** allows simultaneous sending and receiving of signals, enabling more fluid and natural conversations, unlike half-duplex where communication can occur in only one direction at a time.
